stem: A 24-year-old client is 2 days postpartum following a healthy delivery. She was discharged this morning but returns to the ED with a 'blinding headache.' Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: Situation: This is a 24-year-old female, 2 days postpartum, readmitted for severe headache and visual disturbances. Possible postpartum preeclampsia with severe features. Background: G1P1, uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Discharged at 10:00 this morning. No history of hypertension. Assessment: At 16:00, client reports a 'blinding headache' and seeing 'flashes of light.' Blood pressure is 172/112 mmHg, HR 102, RR 22. Reflexes are 4+ with clonus. Urine dipstick shows 3+ protein. Client is agitated and photosensitive. Recommendation: STAT magnesium sulfate protocol. Continuous monitoring of BP, reflexes, and mental status. Neurology consult.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 172/112 mmHg, HR 102, RR 22, SpO2 98% on room air. Edema in ankles is 3+.

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: No radiology orders at this time.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications ordered at this time.

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV Magnesium Sulfate for seizure prophylaxis
Assess deep tendon reflexes and implement seizure precautions
Administer high-dose Naproxen for the headache
Encourage the client to pump breastmilk

rationale.correct: The client's symptoms (severe headache, elevated blood pressure, proteinuria, hyperreflexia with clonus, visual disturbances) are indicative of postpartum preeclampsia with severe features (c1). This condition can occur up to 6 weeks postpartum, even in women without a history of hypertension during pregnancy. The pathophysiology involves endothelial dysfunction and vasospasm, leading to increased blood pressure and potential neurological complications. The priority nursing actions are to initiate IV magnesium sulfate for seizure prophylaxis (a1) and assess deep tendon reflexes while implementing seizure precautions (a2). Magnesium sulfate prevents seizures by acting as a central nervous system depressant. Key parameters to monitor include blood pressure and mental status (p1), as well as headache intensity and vision changes (p2) to assess for worsening cerebral edema or impending stroke.
clinicalPearls: Postpartum preeclampsia/eclampsia can occur up to 6 weeks after delivery, even without prior hypertension.
Magnesium sulfate is neuroprotective and prevents seizures; it does not directly lower blood pressure.
A severe headache with visual disturbances in the postpartum period requires immediate evaluation for preeclampsia/eclampsia.

questionTrap.trap: Administering NSAIDs like Naproxen to treat the headache.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NSAIDs are contraindicated in preeclampsia as they can worsen hypertension and mask neurological symptoms. The priority is to prevent seizures and control blood pressure.

mnemonic.title: HELLP Headache
mnemonic.expansion: H-Hypertension, E-Elevated Liver enzymes, L-Low Platelets, L-Late Postpartum, P-Proteinuria. Headache = Preeclampsia.
